Package com.github.oeuvres.alix.util

Class Chain

java.lang.Object
com.github.oeuvres.alix.util.Chain
All Implemented Interfaces:
Appendable, CharSequence, Comparable<CharSequence>
public class Chain extends Object implements CharSequence, Appendable, Comparable<CharSequence>

A mutable string implementation that grows on the right (Appendable, but also, on the left prepend(char).

The hash function is same as {#link String.hashCode() so that a Chain can be found in a Set<String>.

The same internal char array could be shared by multiple Chain instances (with different offset and size). Some efficient methods are provided, for example, searching by prefix and/or suffix glob(CharSequence).

      public void getChars(char[] dst)

    • getChars

      public void getChars(int srcBegin, int srcEnd, char[] dst, int dstBegin)
      Same as {StringBuffer#getChars()}.
      Parameters:
      srcBegin - start copying at this offset.
      srcEnd - stop copying at this offset.
      dst - the array to copy the data into.
      dstBegin - offset into dst.

    • glob

      public boolean glob(CharSequence text)
      Use this Chain as a glob pattern to match with a charSequence. For example, "maz*" will match with "maze", "mazurka", but not "amaze". "maz?" will match with "maze" but not "mazurka" and "amaze".
      Parameters:
      text - the chars to test.
      Returns:
      true if pattern matches, false otherwise.

    • hashCode

      public int hashCode()
      Returns a hash code for this string. The hash code for a String object is computed as 
       s[0]*31^(n-1) + s[1]*31^(n-2) + ... + s[n-1]
      using int arithmetic, where s[i] is the ith character of the string, n is the length of the string, and ^ indicates exponentiation. (The hash value of the empty string is zero.)
      Overrides:
      hashCode in class Object
      Returns:
      a hash code value for this object.

      public static String normalize(CharSequence cs, char sep)
      Like xpath normalize-space(), normalize a char used as a separator, maybe useful for url paths.
      Parameters:
      cs - the char sequence to normalize.
      sep - the char used as a separator,
      Returns:
      a normalized String.

    • normalize

      public static String normalize(CharSequence cs, String search, char replace)
      Like xpath normalize-space(), replace a set of chars, maybe repeated, for example space chars "\t\n  ", by only one char, for example space ' '.
      Parameters:
      cs - a char sequence to normalize.
      search - a set of chars to normalize ex: "\t\n  ".
      replace - a normalized char ex: ' '.
      Returns:
      a new normalized String.

    • trim

      public Chain trim()
      Suppress spaces at start and end of string. Do not affect the internal char array chars but modify only its limits. Should be very efficient.
      Returns:
      this Chain object (modified).

    • trim

      public Chain trim(String spaces)
      Suppress specific chars at start and end of String. Do not affect the internal char array chars but modify only its limits.
      Parameters:
      spaces - ex: "\n\t ".
      Returns:
      this Chain object (modified).

    • UTF8toUTF16

      public static int UTF8toUTF16(byte[] utf8, int offset, int length, char[] out, int out_offset)
      Copied from lucene to allow UTF-8 bytes conversion to chars from a specific index int the destination char array.

      Interprets the given byte array as UTF-8 and converts to UTF-16. It is the responsibility of the caller to make sure that the destination array is large enough.

      NOTE: Full characters are read, even if this reads past the length passed (and can result in an ArrayOutOfBoundsException if invalid UTF-8 is passed). Explicit checks for valid UTF-8 are not performed.

      Parameters:
      utf8 - source bytes.
      offset - start position in source bytes.
      length - amount of bytes to parse.
      out - destination char array to fill.
      out_offset - start position in destination array.
      Returns:
      the amout of chars appended.
